text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Oxycodone immediate release five milligrams. Patient: Yeah, I’m taking it at night, so you know to get ahead of the pain. But it’s been pretty good. I haven’t been in much hip pain lately, hardly at all. text: Patient: Do they have people that know how to put in an IV? Doctor: Yes they do. Well yeah. Family Member: So you think it would be one IV and then all the drugs through the IV? Doctor: Right. Yeah. Family Member: That’s much better. Doctor: That way you don’t get poked five times. If you have five blood draws. Family Member: So how are you feeling about how he is doing? Patient: Disappointed. Doctor: …this is a slight set back that Xtandi didn’t last us as long as I had hoped it would. And honestly I don’t know if that is part of the sort of resistance of BRC - BRCA mutant disease or not. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Nobody does really at this point because very few people have been really treated with Xtandi up front like that. Family Member: Yeah.

text: Family Member: Actually when you came out it was two point two. And then a week later we went to see his uh - Patient: General practitioner and - Family Member: So what is the reading today? (background noise persists in addition to keyboarding sounds) Patient: Tomorrow I’m going to this local one. I have a schedule with Dr. ___in January because the last neurologist that I saw, the one that put the catheter in, told me the catheter should not be taken out in less than four to six weeks. It should be replaced in every four to six weeks if necessary. Doctor: Sure. Patient: So when I talked to ___, he said okay, then come in January and then we’ll that procedure. So I don’t know if I should go there. I don’t even know what else he can do. I didn’t have chance to talk to him personally. I talked to nurse and she did not explain correctly. text: Family Member: Now, at the end of the trial catheter, how do they go uh with that? Do they have to wait for the catheter to come out in order start clinical trials or or, Doctor: That’s after you’ve sat down with D and signed the paperwork. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Then they’ll do the extra tests to see that you’re eligible. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So there are steps and then if you’re working with a urologist and he or she is able to get it out, that’s great. If they feel like it needs to stay in and that isn’t something that excludes you from the study or that just will tell me that if I’m giving you chemotherapy your blood counts can get low. If your blood counts are low and you’ve got a tube in your bladder, you could have an infection. So that I might give you antibiotics to keep you from getting an infection because you’ve got the tube in. Patient: Um. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it just lets me be aware that I’ve got to be extra careful I’m giving you the chemotherapy. But it could be the one thing that sort of says oh he’s not eligible because he’s got a tube in his body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or maybe they don’t care one bit. Patient: Um.

text: Patient: And that’s the um I guess that’s what’s (pause3secs) Healthcare Professional: Right, you just want to do what you have to, yes, exactly. No, we get that. Patient: So if where where the - we’re looking is probably radiation and sort of like not a complete hormone but like some sort of and I’m probably going to get some sort of a modified sense of a hormonal thing. So I’ll still have some effects of it, but in that effect so that the radiation if we do that part when we target it on what we know where it’s landed, the hormonal will be sort of be keeping everything else at bay at this point. Healthcare Professional: Right. Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. text: Patient: Just in general, I guess. Doctor: Yeah, I think you know, before you make any switch, I would say we touch base, have you touch base with our financial counselors to make sure that you're optimized with everything. I mean, you know, trying to think how old are you? Patient: How old am I? Patient: The older you get the harder it is to remember. I'll be 64 in November. Doctor: So when you qualify for Medicare, is it now or you have to be 65? Patient: I'm the lazy investor. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yeah, the lazy, you know retirement guy. Doctor: Sometimes you can like sign up early for Medicare, because you've got health issues. Those are things we got to get straight before. Yeah. And then Medicare is not all just Medicare, Medicare has dashes attached to Medicare. Some of it is the prescription plan that you need to have. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: So those are things you got to get straight before you do anything else. So we're going to be in deep doo doo. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
